dt: {bc}a feeling of pique or resentment at some often fancied slight or insult

pt: {sc}offense{/sc} {sc}resentment{/sc} {sc}umbrage{/sc} {sc}pique{/sc} {sc}dudgeon{/sc} {sc}huff{/sc} mean an emotional response to or an emotional state resulting from a slight or indignity. {sc}offense{/sc} implies hurt displeasure.
{sc}resentment{/sc} suggests lasting indignation or ill will.

pt.t: harbored a lifelong {it}resentment{/it} of his brother

pt: {sc}umbrage{/sc} may suggest hurt pride, resentment, or suspicion of another's motives.

pt.t: took {it}umbrage{/it} at the offer of advice

pt: {sc}pique{/sc} applies to a transient feeling of wounded vanity.

pt.t: in a {it}pique{/it} I foolishly declined the invitation

pt: {sc}dudgeon{/sc} suggests an angry fit of indignation.

pt.t: stormed out of the meeting in high {it}dudgeon{/it}

pt: {sc}huff{/sc} implies a peevish short-lived spell of anger usually at a petty cause.

pt.t: in a {it}huff{/it} he slammed the door

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin {it}umbraticum{/it}, neuter of {it}umbraticus{/it} of shade, from {it}umbratus{/it}, past participle of {it}umbrare{/it} to shade, from {it}umbra{/it} shade, shadow; akin to Lithuanian {it}unksmė{/it} shadow
shortdef: a feeling of pique or resentment at some often fancied slight or insult
